chapter.htmlHeader: When should I suspect sepsis?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
Be aware that sepsis can be challenging to identify, as the clinical presentation is variable depending on the underlying cause and the person's age and co-morbidities.

  • Suspect sepsis in any person presenting with:
    • Symptoms or signs indicating possible infection causing significant illness or deterioration. This includes people who are deteriorating unexpectedly, or failing to improve as expected.
    • One or more risk factor(s) for sepsis, and who looks unwell.
    • Concern from a relative or carer that there is a change in appearance or behaviour.
  • Be aware that:
    • People with sepsis may present with non-specific, non-localized clinical features, for example general malaise, agitation, or behavioural change.
    • People with sepsis may not present with a high temperature, and may present with hypothermia.
    • Sepsis may result from infection with almost any pathogen, therefore it may present with a wide range of clinical features depending on the site of infection and host response.
  • Suspect neutropenic sepsis in any person who becomes unwell who is receiving anticancer treatment, and manage appropriately. See the CKS topic on Neutropenic sepsis for more information.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on when to suspect sepsis are largely based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) clinical guidelines Sepsis: recognition, assessment and early management [NICE, 2019] and Neutropenic sepsis: prevention and management in people with cancer [NICE, 2012], a consensus document published by a Task Force of the Society of Critical Care Medicine and the European Society of Intensive Care Medicine The Third International Consensus Definitions for Sepsis and Septic Shock (Sepsis-3) [Singer, 2016], the UK Sepsis Trust Sepsis Manual [Daniels, 2017], a Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP) publication Sepsis: guidance for GPs [RCGP, 2018], and expert opinion in review articles on sepsis [Gauer, 2013; Plunkett, 2015; Freitag, 2016; Cecconi, 2018].

  • The recommendation on when to suspect sepsis is based on the NICE clinical guideline on sepsis [NICE, 2019] and expert opinion in the UK Sepsis Trust publication [Daniels, 2017].
    • To reduce avoidable deaths, people with sepsis need to be recognised early and treatment initiated early. The NICE clinical guideline highlights that sepsis is an immediately life-threatening condition that should be recognised and treated as an emergency [NICE, 2019].
  • The information that people with sepsis may have non-specific or non-localized clinical features is based on the experience and opinion of the NICE guideline development group [NICE, 2019], the UK Sepsis Trust publication [Daniels, 2017], and expert opinion in review articles [Plunkett, 2015; Freitag, 2016].
    • Older children may present with a focus of infection, but infants often present with non-specific symptoms and signs, which can lead to late recognition of sepsis [Plunkett, 2015; Freitag, 2016].
  • The information that sepsis may present with hypothermia is based on the UK Sepsis Trust publication [Daniels, 2017] and expert opinion in a review article [Cecconi, 2018].
  • The information that sepsis may present with a range of clinical features is based on expert opinion in review articles [Gauer, 2013; Cecconi, 2018].
  • The recommendation on when to suspect neutropenic sepsis is based on the NICE clinical guideline on neutropenic sepsis [NICE, 2012].
